dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, you know, I was reading this article about Guild Education, and it's pretty fascinating.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host B, you know, I was reading this article about Guild Education, and it's pretty fascinating.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, Guild! That's the company that helps, like, McDonald's and Taco Bell, uh, offer degrees to their employees, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, Guild! That's the company that helps, like, McDonald's and Taco Bell, uh, offer degrees to their employees, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And it's not just, um, a nice-to-have. Guild's CEO, Rachel Carlson, was at this Forbes summit, and she said it actually *lifts profits*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And it's not just, um, a nice-to-have. Guild's C E O, Rachel Carlson, was at this Forbes summit, and she said it actually lifts profits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson says it's because nearly every CEO they work with has mentioned sending their employees back to school as something 'good' in their earnings call. It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Profits? Really? I mean, I always thought it was, like, good PR for companies, you know, showing they care.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Profits? Really? I mean, I always thought it was, like, good P R for companies, you know, showing they care.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that too, but she's saying it's way more. It leads to higher retention, better recruitment, upskilling... [overlaps]
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that too, but she's saying it's way more. It leads to higher retention, better recruitment, upskilling...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the last number of years weve proven that when companies invest in their frontline workforce they become more attractive for people to work at the company and stay at the company [with] higher retention rates, higher recruitment rates, higher up-scaling rates and a more positive brand as a corporate company in America, Guild cofounder and CEO Rachel Carlson said at the Forbes Women's Summit last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] So it's not just a feel-good thing. It's actually a smart business move.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's not just a feel-good thing. It's actually a smart business move.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And, uh, they've got some big names on board. Walmart, for example, their Live Better U program?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And, uh, they've got some big names on board. Walmart, for example, their Live Better U program?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, where employees pay, like, a dollar a day for tuition?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, where employees pay, like, a dollar a day for tuition?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet not everyone is convinced. When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Mmm-hmm. After financial aid, it covers pretty much everything. It's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mmm-hmm. After financial aid, it covers pretty much everything. It's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's incredible. But, uh, the article did mention some skepticism, right? Like Stephanie Ruhle from MSNBC?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's incredible. But, uh, the article did mention some skepticism, right? Like Stephanie Ruhle from M S N B C?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson was joined on-stage by Rothy's President Kerry Whorton Cooper, The Cru Founder & CEO Tiffany Dufu, MSNBC anchor Stephanie Ruhle and Vanguard's Head of U.S. Wealth Planning Research Maria Bruno.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah. She was like, "I've never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing." [chuckles]
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah. She was like, I've never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Fair point! But Carlson's argument is that CEOs *do* mention sending employees back to school in earnings calls, not just to pat themselves on the back, but because it shows...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fair point! But Carlson's argument is that C E Os do mention sending employees back to school in earnings calls, not just to pat themselves on the back, but because it shows...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson says it's because nearly every CEO they work with has mentioned sending their employees back to school as something 'good' in their earnings call. It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: ...it shows improved profits, recruitment, and retention. It's a tangible benefit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...it shows improved profits, recruitment, and retention. It's a tangible benefit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's about the bottom line, which, um, makes sense why companies like Chipotle and Disney are lining up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's about the bottom line, which, um, makes sense why companies like Chipotle and Disney are lining up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So why exactly are companies like Chipotle, Discover and Walt Disney lining up to offer nearly free education to employees?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And it's really targeting, like, 64 million frontline and low-income workers who need further education because of automation, you know? Cashiers, restaurant staff...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And it's really targeting, like, sixty four million frontline and low-income workers who need further education because of automation, you know? Cashiers, restaurant staff...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While many corporate education programs focus on white collar workers, Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world. This group includes cashiers, customer service representatives, restaurant wait staff and cooks, and more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's a massive group. But, uh, what about the gig economy? The article brought up Lyft.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a massive group. But, uh, what about the gig economy? The article brought up Lyft.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Guild is now looking at how to expand education options to workers in the gig economy. Though Lyft is currently a client offering some educational perks, drivers are not able to receive tuition reimbursement the way other employees might.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, that's their next big hurdle. Lyft's a client, but because of the tax code, they can't offer drivers the same tuition reimbursement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, that's their next big hurdle. Lyft's a client, but because of the tax code, they can't offer drivers the same tuition reimbursement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though Lyft is currently a client offering some educational perks, drivers are not able to receive tuition reimbursement the way other employees might. That's because the tax code doesn't allow companies to provide nontaxable education assistance to those workers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [sighs] Ah, the tax code always complicates things, doesn't it? So, they're lobbying to change that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah, the tax code always complicates things, doesn't it? So, they're lobbying to change that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lobbying to change this tax incentive might be the company's greatest hurdle yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Mmm-hmm. It's, uh, a big barrier, even with all that funding they've gotten.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mmm-hmm. It's, uh, a big barrier, even with all that funding they've gotten.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition to serving 3 million employees, the company has attracted over $70 million in funding from firms like Bessemer Venture Partners, Cowboy Ventures and Silicon Valley Bank. Guild is now looking at how to expand education options to workers in the gig economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Fascinating. So, investing in your workforce isn't just good for people, it's good for business.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fascinating. So, investing in your workforce isn't just good for people, it's good for business.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. A win-win, if they can figure out the gig worker piece.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. A win-win, if they can figure out the gig worker piece.
